name: 3,3,3-trifluoro-N-(1-methylpropyl)-2-(trifluoromethyl)propanamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3479
Reason: 1,3-dioxolane has a melting point of -106.0 degrees Celsius. The basic unit for our comparison will be 1,3-dioxane, which has a melting point of -106.0 degrees Celsius. The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Additionally, the methyl group introduces a rigid structure, which can participate in hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point by approximately +10°C. The trifluoromethyl group introduces a significant increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, estimated at approximately +20°C. The fluorine atoms also increase the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and the rigid structure, estimated at approximately +10°C each.
